'''Order''' is the planning of [[time]] and organizing of [[resource]]s, as well as of society.<ref>[[Erving Goffman]], ''Relations in Public'' (1972) p. 15</ref>
Although order is rarely discussed as a virtue in contemporary society, order is in fact central to improving [[efficiency]], and is at the heart of [[time management]] strategies such as David Allen's ''[[Getting Things Done]]''.
==Emergence== The valorisation of order in the early stages of commercialization and industrialisation was linked by [[R. H. Tawney]] to Puritan concerns for system and method in 17th-century England.<ref>R. H. Tawney, ''Religion and the Rise of Capitalism'' (1937) p. 193-5</ref> The same period saw English prose developing the qualities [[Matthew Arnold]] described as "regularity, uniformity, precision, balance".<ref>Quoted in Deirdre N. McCloskey, ''The Bourgeois Virtues'' (2006) p. 164</ref>
"Let all your things have their places; let each part of your business have its time" is a saying attributed to [[Benjamin Franklin]] in 1730, while he was 20 years old. It was part of his 13 [[virtue]]s.<ref>{{Cite web |first=Benjamin |last=Franklin |url=http://www.earlyamerica.com/lives/franklin/chapt8/ |title=The Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin: Chapter Eight |publisher=earlyamerica.com }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |first=Ron |last=Kurtus |date=7 February 2005 |url=http://www.school-for-champions.com/character/franklin_virtues.htm |title=Benjamin Franklin's Thirteen Virtues |publisher=school-for-champions.com }}</ref>
A darker view of the early modern internalisation of order and discipline was taken by [[Michel Foucault]] in ''The Order of Things'' and ''Discipline and Punish'';<ref>G. Gutting ed., ''The Cambridge Companion to Foucault'' (2002) p. 97-9</ref> but for [[Rousseau]] love of order both in nature and in the harmonious psyche of the natural man was one of the tap-roots of moral conscience.<ref>Lawrence D. Cooper, ''Rousseau, Nature, and the Problem of the Good Life'' (2006) p. 92-6</ref>
==Romantic reaction==
The [[Romanticism|Romantic]] reaction against reason, industry and the sober virtues, led to a downgrading of order as well.<ref>McCloskey, p. 31-2 and p. 69</ref> In art, spontaneity took precedence over method and craft;<ref>M. H. Abrams, ''The mirror and the lamp'' (1971) p. 24</ref> in life, the [[Bohemianism|Bohemian]] call of wildness and disorder eclipsed the appeal of ordered sobriety – as with the cultivated disorganization of the [[sixties]] [[hippie]].<ref>E. Hoffman ed., ''Future Visions'' (1996) p. 144</ref>
"Latter-day attempts such as those of [[Deidre McCloskey]] to reclaim the bourgeois virtues like order may be met in some quarters only by laughter."<ref>McCloskey, p. 5</ref>
==Sociology== Sociologists, while noting that praise of order is generally associated with a conservative stance – one that can be traced back through [[Edmund Burke]] and [[Richard Hooker]] to [[Aristotle]]<ref>Shelley Burke, ''Virtue Transformed'' (2006) p. 54</ref> - point out that many taken-for-granted aspects of [[social order]] (such as which side of the road to drive on) produce substantial and equitable advantages for individuals at very little personal cost.<ref>Goffman, p. 16</ref> Conversely, breakdowns in [[public order]] reveal everyone's daily dependence upon the smooth functioning of the wider society.<ref>Goffman p. 16-17</ref>
[[Durkheim]] saw [[anomie]] as the existential reaction to the ordered disorder of modern society.<ref>John O'Neill, ''Sociology as a Skin Trade'' (1972) p. 181</ref>
==Psychology== [[Jung]]ians considered orderliness (along with restraint and responsibility) as one of the virtues attributable to the [[senex]] or old man - as opposed to the spontaneous openness of the [[Puer Aeternus|puer]] or eternal youth.<ref>M. Jacoby, ''The Analytic Encounter'' (1984) p. 118</ref>
[[Freud]] saw the positive traits of orderliness and conscientiousness as rooted in [[anal eroticism]].<ref>Sigmund Freud, ''On Sexuality'' (PFL 7) p. 209</ref>
==20th-century examples== Freud himself was a highly organised personality, ordering his life – at work and play – with the regularity of a timetable.<ref>Peter Gay, ''Freud'' (1989) p. 157</ref>
[[William Osler]] was another highly successful physician who built his life on a highly organised basis.<ref>Eric Berne, ''What Do You Say After You Say Hello?'' (1974) p. 268</ref>
==Culture== [[Wallace Stevens]] wrote of the "blessed rage for order" in ''Ideas of Order'' (1936).<ref>Wallace Stevens, ''Collected Poems'' (1984) p. 130</ref>
==See also== * [[Conscientiousness]] * [[Convention (norm)|Convention]] * [[Norm (social)|Norm]] * [[Orderliness]] * [[Prudence]] * [[Temperance (virtue)|Temperance]]
==References== {{Reflist|2|}}
==Further reading== William Osler, ''Aequanimitas'' (New York 1963)
==External links== {{Wiktionary|order}}

revision.text:
'''The Pacific Northwest Labor and Civil Rights History Projects''' are a series of multimedia public history initiatives. The projects cover a range of themes and subjects in the Northwest and Seattle, with a particular focus on working people and their movements. The effort, particularly the [[Seattle Civil Rights and Labor History Project]], has garnered praise for the breadth of primary and secondary resources made available and its joint creation by academics, community members and hundreds of students. It has been recognized as a model of digital and publicly engaged scholarship.<ref name=Dublin>{{cite journal|last=Dublin|first=Thomas|title=The New Labor History, the New Media, and New Challenges|journal=Labor: Studies in Working-Class History of the Americas|date=Summer 2010|volume=7|issue=2|pages=83–96 |url=http://depts.washington.edu/labhist/labor_review.pdf|doi=10.1215/15476715-2009-078}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Klinetobe|first=Charles|title=Review:The Seattle Civil Rights and Labor History Project|url=http://digitalhistory.unl.edu//p-reviews/seattleklinetobe.php|work=Digital History Project|publisher=University of Nebraska-Lincoln}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Griffey|first=Trevor|title=Rethinking Race and Place: The Seattle Civil Rights and Labor History Project|journal=OAH Magazine of History|date=January 2012|volume=26|issue=1|pages=47–50|url=http://maghis.oxfordjournals.org/content/26/1/47.full?keytype=ref&ijkey=IeFmtkRZYTKf7CO|doi=10.1093/oahmag/oar049}}</ref>
==Projects== The primary projects in the series are the [[Seattle Civil Rights and Labor History Project]], [[Great Depression in Washington State Project|the Great Depression in Washington State Project]], [[Waterfront workers history project|the Waterfront Workers History Project]], [[the Labor Press Project]], [[Seattle General Strike Project|the Seattle General Strike Project]], [[Communism in Washington State History and Memory Project|the Communism in Washington State Project]] and the Antiwar and Radical History Project. The [[Strikes! Labor History Encyclopedia for the Pacific Northwest]] draws together the resources available on the other sites and adds additional information on workers from the many industries and communities of the region.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gregory|first=James|author2=Trevor Griffey|title=Seattle Civil Rights & Labor History Project: an Online Video Oral History Collection|journal=Northwest Oral History Association Newsletter|date=Spring 2007|url=http://depts.washington.edu/civilr3/pdf/NOHA%20Spring%2007.pdf}}</ref> Many of these resources are only digitized and available through the projects, having been culled from archival material and personal collections and materials including the only known film of the 1919 Seattle General Strike and the 1934 West Coast Waterfront Strike are exceedingly rare.
==Impact== The Projects have gained attention as a trailblazing initiative in public scholarship and engagement between the University of Washington and the Seattle community to record histories like [http://depts.washington.edu/civilr/Cannery_intro.htm Filipino Cannery Unionism] and the [[Chicano/a Movement in Washington State History Project|Chicano Movement in Washington State]] that are largely unavailable elsewhere. A unique, collaborative process has also given community members greater control over content than traditional academic research and created more investment by students in their work <ref>{{cite journal|last=Cole|first=Peter|title=Web Site Review: Seattle Civil Rights and Labor History Project|journal=Journal of American History|date=March 2008|volume=95|issue=4|url=http://www.journalofamericanhistory.org/issues/954/wr4.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110070938/http://www.journalofamericanhistory.org/issues/954/wr4.html|archivedate=2013-11-10|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Rosales-Castaneda|first=Oscar|title=Writing Chicana/o History with the Seattle Civil Rights and Labor History Project|journal=Writing History in the Digital Age|date=Spring 2012|url=http://writinghistory.trincoll.edu/public-history/rosales-castaneda-2012-spring/}}</ref> The impact of the Projects beyond the academic realm was demonstrated when Washington State law on neighborhood association covenants changed as a result of information brought to light on racially exclusive housing covenants that remained in neighborhood charters.<ref>{{cite news|last=Turnbull|first=Lornet|title=Homeowners find records still hold blot of racism|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2002297312_covenants03m.html|newspaper=Seattle Times|date=June 3, 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Gregory|first=James|title=Stain of racism still haunts Seattle neighborhoods|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/opinion/2002913362_jamesgregory06.html|newspaper=Seattle Times|date=April 6, 2006}}</ref> In other cases, the projects have brought light to rarely studied stories, like the Seattle Black Panther Party. The local Chapter was one of the first founded outside Oakland and one of the longest lived. The Civil Rights and Labor History Project unearthed material and conducted oral histories that form the largest body of material on any Party chapter in the nation, including the founding chapter in Oakland.<ref>{{cite news|last=Solomon|first=Cara|title=The story of Seattle's Black Panther Party|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2003009057_blackpanthers21m.html|newspaper=Seattle Times|date=May 21, 2006}}</ref> All of the projects have been notable for the quantity of material made available online. The Labor Press Project hosts thousands of digitized articles from more than thirty different union and radical newspapers, and the Strikes! Labor History Encyclopedia contains a day-by-day database of articles from the Northwest related to labor covering the crucial periods of 1915-1919 and 1930-1939. Video oral histories are key part of the projects, showing first-hand perspectives that are placed alongside original academic essays and digitized historical materials.<ref name=Dublin /> The Projects have also focused on outreach to Washington Public Schools, working with educators to design curriculum using the materials to teach students about the sometimes forgotten history of labor and civil rights in the Northwest and fulfill State requirements.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gregory|first=James|author2=Trevor Griffey|title=Teaching a City about Its Civil Rights History: A Public History Success Story|journal=Perspectives|date=April 2007|volume=45|issue=4|url=http://www.historians.org/Perspectives/issues/2007/0704/index.cfm}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://depts.washington.edu/labhist/ Pacific Northwest Labor and Civil Rights History Projects] * [http://depts.washington.edu/labhist/encyclopedia/ Strikes! Labor History Encyclopedia for the Pacific Northwest]

revision.text:
'''Parental alienation''' is the process, and the result, of [[psychological manipulation]] of a child into showing unwarranted fear, disrespect or hostility towards a parent and/or other family members.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0">{{cite book|last1=Warshak|first1=Richard A.|title=Divorce Poison|date=2009|publisher=Harper Collins|isbn=978-0061984235|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QRkMjqXrmsIC|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> It is a distinctive form of psychological abuse, towards both the child and the rejected family members, that occurs almost exclusively in association with family separation or divorce, particularly where legal action is involved.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The High-Conflict Custody Battle: Protect Yourself and Your Kids from a Toxic Divorce, False Accusations, and Parental Alienation|last = Baker|first = AJL|publisher = New Harbinger|year = 2014|isbn = 9781626250734|location = Oakland, USA|pages = }}</ref> It undermines core principles of both the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] and the United Nations [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]]. Most commonly, the primary cause is a parent wishing to exclude another parent from the life of their child, but other family members or friends, as well as professionals involved with the family (including psychologists, lawyers and judges), may contribute significantly to the process.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|url = http://aaml.org/sites/default/files/MAT107_7.pdf|title = Parental Alienation: Overview, Management, Intervention, and Practice Tips.|last = Warshak|first = R.A.|date = 2015|journal = Journal of the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers|doi = |pmid = |access-date = 1 October 2017}}</ref> It often leads to the long-term, or even permanent, [[Family estrangement|estrangement]] of a child from one parent and other family members<ref>{{Cite book|title = Adult Children of Parental Alienation: Breaking the Ties that Bind|last = Baker|first = Amy, J.L.|publisher = W.W. Norton & Co.|year = 2007|isbn = 978-0393705195|location = |pages = }}</ref> and, as a particularly [[Adverse Childhood Experiences Study|adverse childhood experience]], results in significantly increased lifetime risks of both mental and physical illness.<ref name="bernetw"/>
== Overview == First described in 1976 as "pathological alignment", parental alienation refers to a situation in which a child unreasonably rejects a non-custodial parent.<ref name = Bow2009>{{cite journal | last = Bow | first = JN |author2=Gould JW |author3=Flens JR | year = 2009 | title = Examining Parental Alienation in Child Custody Cases: A Survey of Mental Health and Legal Professionals | journal = The American Journal of Family Therapy | volume = 37 | issue = 2 | pages = 127–145 | doi = 10.1080/01926180801960658|url=http://www.drjamesrflens.com/_Bow_et_al.__2009___Examing_parental_alienation_in_child_custody_case.pdf }}</ref> [[Richard A. Gardner]] proposed [[parental alienation syndrome]] in the 1980s based on his clinical experience with the children of divorcing parents. Parental alienation lacks a single definition and its existence, cause and characteristics have been the subject of debate. Gardner's concept of a syndrome has failed to gain acceptance. Some [[empirical research]] has been performed, though the quality of the studies vary widely and research in the area is still developing.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Hands | first1 = A. J. | last2 = Warshak | first2 = R. A. | year = 2011 | title = Parental Alienation Among College Students | url = | journal = The American Journal of Family Therapy | volume = 39 | issue = 5| pages = 431–443 | doi=10.1080/01926187.2011.575336}}</ref>
A survey of literature suggests that alienating behaviors by both parents are common in high-conflict divorces.<ref name = Bow2009/> Rejected parents tend to lose a sense of warmth and empathy with the child. As a result, the rejected parent may become passive, depressed, anxious, and withdrawn – characteristics that may encourage further rejection. The parent that the child aligns with (the aligned parent) may engage in alienating behaviors, including undermining the other parent. These behaviors may be conscious and deliberate or may reflect a lack of awareness on the effect of the actions on the children. Direct alienating behaviors occur when one parent actively undermines the other parent, such as making derogatory remarks about the other parent, telling the child that the other parent is responsible for the separation, or telling the child that the other parent is the cause of financial difficulties. Indirect alienation behaviors occur when one parent fails to support access or contact with the other parent or tacitly accepts the child's negative behaviour and comments towards the other parent.<ref name = Bow2009/><ref name = Bala2007/>
=== Causes === The causes of alienation can be divided into two broad categories, *Realistic estrangement, in which a parent's harmful or abusive behaviors or substance abuse result in the alienation of the child;<ref name=acorn/> and *Pathological alienation, in which the alienation results from pathological aspects of the child's family relationships, and is not a rational response to the behavior of the alienated parent. Realistic estrangement is a different phenomenon from "pathological alienation". The former is an understandable refusal by a child to see an [[child abuse|abusive]] parent, while the latter is emotionally harmful and unjustified.<ref name = Bala2007/>
=== Symptoms === Symptoms associated with parental alienation include: *The child engages in a pattern of "denigration" against a targeted parent for unjustified reasons and uses "frivolous rationalizations" that are "disproportionate" to the circumstances.<ref name=inq/> *The child may display a "complete lack of ambivalence" wherein the rejected parent is viewed as "all bad" and the favored parent is viewed as "all good."<ref name=echo/> This lack of ambivalence is associated with "[[Splitting (psychology)|splitting]]."<ref name="newsweek2014">{{cite journal|title=Bernet et al. (2017). An Objective Measure of Splitting in Parental Alienation: The Parental Acceptance-Rejection Questionnaire. Journal of Forensic Sciences. doi: 10.1111/1556-4029.13625|journal=Journal of Forensic Sciences|volume=63|issue=3|pages=776–783|last1=Bernet|first1=William|last2 = Gregory|first2=Nilgun|last3=Reay|first3=Kathleen M.|last4=Rohner|first4=Ronald P.|doi=10.1111/1556-4029.13625|pmid=28833110|year = 2018}}</ref> Splitting refers to a primitive division of the ego into "all good" and "all bad" objects to prevent the "generalization of anxiety."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Kernberg, O. F. (1995). Borderline Conditions and Pathological Narcissism.|last=|first=|publisher=Jason Aronson, Inc.|year=1995|isbn=9780876681770|edition= Reissue|location=Princeton, NJ|pages=|language=English}}</ref> *The child may display "reflexive support" for the parent they favor during disagreements between the rejected parent and the favored parent.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://psychlaw.net/criteria-for-the-diagnosis-of-parental-alienation/|title=Lorandos, D. (2016). "Criteria for the Diagnosis of Parental Alienation." PsychLaw.net|last=|first=|date=|website=www.psychlaw.net|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 August 2018}}</ref> *The child may use "borrowed scenarios" that involve making "identical" statements to those of the "alienating parent" when the alienating parent makes disparaging comments against the rejected parent.<ref name=":1" /> *The child may display an "independent thinker phenomenon" which involves comments by the child that their decision to reject the targeted parent was arrived at without any influence from the alienating parent.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Baker, J. L. & Darnall, D. C. (2007). A Construct Study of the Eight Symptoms of Severe Parental Alienation Syndrome. Journal of Divorce & Remarriage, 47(1-2).|journal=Journal of Divorce & Remarriage|volume=47|pages=55–75|doi=10.1300/J087v47n01_04|year = 2007|last1 = Baker|first1 = Amy J. L.|last2=Damall|first2=Douglas C.}}</ref> *The child may display an "absence of guilt" regarding their denigration of the targeted parent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fact.on.ca/Info/pas/gard02c.htm|title=Gardner, R. A. (2002). The Empowerment of Children in the Development of Parental Alienation Syndrome. The American Journal of Forensic Psychology, 20(2), 5-29.|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=19 August 2018}}</ref> *The child's vilification of the targeted parent spreads to "extended family" members.<ref name=":2" />
==Theories== Some researchers emphasized the role of an alienating parent, termed variously the "programming" parent or "embittered-chaotic parent",<ref name = Bow2009/> while other researchers have focused on the "alienated child", and the relationship dynamics that contribute to the alienation.<ref name="Bala2007">{{cite journal |last = Bala|first = N|author2 = Fidler B|author3 = Goldberg D|author4 = Houston C|year = 2007|journal = Queens Law Journal|volume = 33|title = Alienated Children and Parental Separation: Legal Responses from Canada's Family Courts|pages = 79–138|url = http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?collection=journals&handle=hein.journals/queen33&div=7&id=&page=}}</ref><ref name=Jaffe2002>{{cite book |last=Jaffe |first=PG |author2=Lemon NKD |author3=Poisson SE |title=Child Custody & Domestic Violence |publisher=[[SAGE Publications]] |year=2002 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=bbZmp7ALOq4C&pg=PA52 52–54] |isbn=978-0-7619-1826-4}}</ref>
Within the context of relationship dynamics, alienation is seen as a breakdown of [[attachment (psychology)|attachment]] between parent and child that may be caused by a variety factors. These researchers have proposed a more complex analysis, in which all family members may play a role in the alienation. This "systems-based" view acknowledges that a child may be alienated from one parent with no alienation programming from the other parent.<ref name = Bow2009/><ref name = Bala2007/> The behaviors of all family members, including those of the alienated parent, may lead to [[family dysfunction]] and the rejection of a parent.<ref name= Ackerman2001>{{cite book |author=Ackerman MJ |title=Clinician's guide to child custody evaluations |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] |location=New York |year=2001 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=q9E_rg94Cs4C&pg=PA73 73–82] |isbn=978-0-471-39260-6}}</ref><ref name=Waldron1996>{{cite journal |last=Waldron |first=KH |author2=Joanis DE |url= http://fact.on.ca/Info/pas/waldron.htm |title=Understanding and Collaboratively Treating Parental Alienation Syndrome |journal=American Journal of Family Law |volume=10 |pages= 121–133 |year=1996}}</ref> Under this approach, when a child is estranged from a parent it is necessary to evaluate all contributing factors and all possible remedies to the estrangement.<ref name=Bala2007/><ref name=Sparta2006>{{cite book |last=Sparta |first=SN |author2=Koocher GP |title=Forensic Mental Health Assessment of Children and Adolescents |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=2006 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=6bmBtQ2Zl-IC&pg=PA83 83], [https://books.google.com/books?id=6bmBtQ2Zl-IC&pg=PA219 219–221] |isbn=978-0-19-514584-7}}</ref>
===Motivation=== In one conception of parental alienation, driven by a specific parent, a parent who experienced feelings of inadequacy or abandonment in their childhood can have those feelings re-triggered by a divorce or breakup. In response, that parent can [[Repetition compulsion#Postmodern formulations|reenact]]<ref name=acorn/><ref name=Pingitore2015/><ref name=Pearlman2005>{{cite journal | last=Pearlman | first=Laurie| title=Clinical Applications of the Attachment Framework: Relational Treatment of Complex Trauma | journal=Journal of Traumatic Stress | volume=18 | issue= 5| year = 2005 | pages=449–459 | doi= 10.1002/jts.20052| pmid=16281242| url=http://delphicentre.com.au/uploads/Pearlman,%20L.A.,%20Courtois,%20C.%20%282005%29%20RelationalTxofCmplxtTrauma.JTS.pdf}}</ref><ref name=Levy1998>{{cite journal | last=Levy | first=Michael| title=A Helpful Way to Conceptualize and Understand Reenactments | journal = The Journal of Psychotherapy Practice and Research | volume=7 | issue=3 | year = 1998 | pages=227–235 | doi= | pmc=3330499 | pmid=9631344}}</ref><ref name=Sadock>{{cite book|author=Benjamin Sadock PhD|title=Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry|publisher=LWWW|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=ubG51n2NgfwC&pg=PA261&lpg=PA261&dq=trauma+reenactment+textbook&source=bl&ots=tn2C5lygwY&sig=ejbMNsLZBQcOKx03tKH1Su74ebI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CIcBEOgBMAlqFQoTCO_K7vPjgcgCFcFxPgodWvYFkw#v=onepage&q=trauma%20reenactment%20textbook&f=false 216]|isbn=978-0781787468|year=2008}}</ref><ref name=Kolk1997>{{cite journal | last=van der Kolk | first=B.A.| title=The psychological consequences of overwhelming life experiences | journal=Psychological Trauma | volume=7 | issue=3 | year = 1987 | pages=5 | doi= | url= }}</ref><ref name=Kolk2005>{{cite journal | last=van der Kolk | first=B.A.| title=Developmental Trauma Disorder: Towards a rational diagnosis for children with complex trauma histories. | journal=Psychiatric Annals | volume=35 | issue=5 | year = 2005 | pages=401–408 | doi= | url=http://www.traumacenter.org/products/pdf_files/preprint_dev_trauma_disorder.pdf}}</ref><ref name=Reyes2008>{{cite book |last=Reyes |first=Gilbert |author2=Elhai Jon |title=The Encyclopedia of Psychological Trauma |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] |year=2000 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=O3rSIn_qTkAC&pg=PT1119&dq=The+Encyclopedia+of+Psychological+Trauma+reenactment&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMI852c5f2MyAIVw6uACh1BCAJL#v=snippet&q=Reenactment&f=false 0] |isbn=978-0470110065}}</ref><ref name=LeadershipCouncilBrain>{{cite web|last1=van der Kolk|first1=BA|title=The compulsion to repeat the trauma|url=http://www.leadershipcouncil.org/1/res/brain.html|website=The Leadership Council on Child Abuse & Interpersonal Violence : The Effect of Childhood Trauma on Brain Development |accessdate=5 December 2015}}</ref> a false narrative related to their own childhood, where the child's other parent symbolizes an inadequate or abusive parent, the child symbolizes a victim of the other parent, and the parent using harmful parenting practices symbolizes a good parent ostensibly trying to protect their child.<ref name=Fidler>{{cite book|author=Barbara Jo Fidler|title=Children Who Resist Postseparation Parental Contact: A Differential Approach for Legal and Mental Health Professionals |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=ocUupL4YcnkC&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=%22Parental+alienation+and+the+DSM+V%22&source=bl&ots=AAdSCewGoX&sig=oZCnKkZpvL-M-J6Ckbf2p5Bp3tg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CD8Q6AEwBWoVChMI2IzqnvGxyAIVS5qACh3_WQDE#v=onepage&q=%22the%20favored%20parent%20may%20have%20a%20personality%20disorder%20or%20mental%20illness%22&f=false 30]|isbn=978-0199895496|date=2012-09-13 }}</ref> The role of the bystander such as friends, therapists, and judges is to confirm the delusion for the parent, which was already partially confirmed for them by the child acting like a victim<ref name=acorn/><ref name=Greenfield2015/><ref name=newsweek2014/><ref name=Pearlman2005/> However, in reality, the other parent is neither inadequate nor abusive; rather, the parent using the harmful parenting practices is abusive.<ref name=acorn/><ref name=Pingitore2015/><ref name=Greenfield2015/> In effect, the parent who fears inadequacy or abandonment is able to [[Psychological projection|project]] their fears onto the other parent<ref name=acorn/> because "all can plainly see" that it is the other parent who is rejected and abandoned by the child and who is "inadequate".<ref name=echo/>
A parent who uses harmful parenting practices may suffer from [[borderline personality disorder]] or [[narcissistic personality disorder]],<ref name=inq/><ref name=acorn/><ref name=echo/><ref name=stines2015/><ref name=Greenfield2015/><ref name=Fidler/> related to an experience of feeling inadequate or abandoned while growing up. This feeling can be re-triggered by a divorce or breakup, causing them to [[Decompensation#Psychology|decompensate]] into [[persecutory delusions]].<ref name=Pingitore2015/><ref name=stines2015/><ref name=Fidler/><ref name=Millon2011>{{cite book |author=Theodore Million|title=Disorders of Personality:Introducing a DSM / ICD Spectrum from Normal to Abnormal 3rd Edition|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]]|year=2011 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=-u5lAsunPu0C&pg=PA407&dq=millon+persecutory+delusion+decompensation+%22Under+conditions+of+unrelieved+adversity+and+failure%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAWoVChMI48v_nsrZxwIVC8uACh09uAUy#v=onepage&q=millon%20persecutory%20delusion%20decompensation%20%22Under%20conditions%20of%20unrelieved%20adversity%20and%20failure%22&f=false 407–408] |isbn=978-0470040935}}</ref><ref name=Masterson1981>{{cite book |author=James Masterson, M.D.|title=The Narcissistic and Borderline Disorders: An Integrated Developmental Approach|publisher=[[Routledge]]|year=1981 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=grUdWczSIoUC&pg=PA38&lpg=PA38&dq=acute+psychotic+decompensation+with+paranoid+ideation&source=bl&ots=gU5fr-nUqr&sig=3sJZQo8yyj6IcFoXP8lfhr6XvZE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAGoVChMIuMfR4J7axwIViBweCh2nWAh-#v=onepage&q=acute%20psychotic%20decompensation%20with%20acute%20paranoid%20ideation&f=false 38] |isbn=978-0876302927}}</ref> These parents may believe that they do not need to follow social norms of fairness,<ref name=inq/><ref name=echo/> and they may "parentify their own children",<ref name=Oldham2007parentify>{{cite book|last1=Oldham|first1=John M.|last2=Skodol|first2=Andrew E.|last3=Bender|first3=Donna S.|title=The American Psychiatric Publishing Textbook of Personality Disorders|date=2007|publisher=American Psychiatric Publishing|isbn=978-1585626625|pages=364|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gxpXTm9T1MsC&pg=PA364|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> "excessively bind their children to themselves",<ref name=Oldham2007parentify/> "demand absolute, unlimited control over their children while threatening rejection",<ref name=Oldham2007parentify/> project their own fears onto the other parent,<ref name=Oldham2007parentify/> abandon their spouse in favor of their children,<ref name=Oldham2007parentify/> and revive their own childhood attachment trauma after a difficult experience.<ref name=Oldham2007parentify/>
===Mechanism=== The techniques of harmful parenting may be subtle and "genuine".<ref name=inq/><ref name=acorn/><ref name=Fidler/> A parent can [[Triangulation (psychology)|triangulate]] the child into the marital conflict<ref name="irishtimes">{{cite web |last1=Gartland |first1=Fiona |title=Jail time for parental alienation not in best interests of children |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/jail-time-for-parental-alienation-not-in-best-interests-of-children-1.2350370 |website=Irish Times |accessdate=29 September 2015}}</ref> by encouraging the child to make even minor complaints about the other parent and then "enthusiastically validating" them. This signals to the child that the other parent is dangerous<ref name=echo/><ref name="BakerSurviving">{{cite web |last1=Baker |first1=Amy |title=Surviving Parental Alienation, Part 2: The parental alienation tipping point |url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/caught-between-parents/201410/surviving-parental-alienation-part-2|website=Psychology Today |accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref>{{mcn|date=November 2017}} and insensitive.<ref name=echo/><ref name=BakerSurviving/> This encouragement to complain manipulates the child into the role of victim without the child's awareness,<ref name=stines2015/><ref name=BakerSurviving/> allowing the parent to move into the protector role, forcing the other parent into the "inadequate" parent role, and leaving no trace of what happened for bystanders who only see the child acting as a "victim".<ref name=echo/><ref name=Greenfield2015/><ref name=newsweek2014/> Over time, the combined effects of growing closer to the alienating parent through this complaining process<ref name=echo/> and growing further from the rejected parent as the result of focusing on negative things about the other parent cause the child to reject their other parent as being inadequate.
A parent may also mix in [[lie]]s,<ref name=echo/> partial lies,<ref name=BakerSurviving/>{{ums|date=November 2017}} and [[exaggerations]],<ref name=echo/> particularly ones that the child may not be able to verify or where only the true part of the partial lie is easy to verify.<ref name=toxicex>{{cite book|last1=Baker|first1=Amy|title=Coparenting with a Toxic Ex|date=2014|publisher=New Harbinger Publications|isbn=978-1608829583|pages=85–86}}</ref> As the result of being encouraged to act as judge of their rejected parent,<ref name=echo/> the child then feels superior to their rejected parent, leading to the symptoms of [[grandiosity]], entitlement, and haughty arrogance. This feeds the [[delusion]] of the parent, that they are protecting the child from an inadequate parent.<ref name=Greenfield2015/> The child then begins to adopt this [[delusion]] also.<ref name=acorn/><ref name=echo/><ref name=newsweek2014/>
Because the child and parent are from different generations, this qualifies as a [[Triangulation (psychology)#The Perverse Triangle|perverse triangle]],<ref name=Gottlieb2012>{{cite book|author=Linda Gottlieb|title=THE PARENTAL ALIENATION SYNDROME: A Family Therapy and Collaborative Systems Approach to Amelioration|publisher=Charles C Thomas|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=WMTwCAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=linda+gottlieb+the+parental+alienation+syndrome&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAGoVChMIurOG0IWOyAIVTI6SCh3zGANw#v=onepage&q=perverse%20triangle&f=false 4,87,180,214,222,249,254,258,259]|isbn=978-0398087364|year=2012}}</ref><ref name=BakerWorking>{{cite book|author=Amy J. L. Baker PhD|title=WORKING WITH ALIENATED FAMILIES A Clinical Guidebook|publisher=Routeledge|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Rxq-Bsj18ZgC&pg=PT172&lpg=PT172&dq=#v=onepage&q=perverse%20triangle&f=false 200, 230,238]|isbn=978-0415518031|year=2013}}</ref> further complicated by [[enmeshment]],<ref name=LudmerIntervention/><ref name=Goldstein>{{cite book|author=Mark Goldstein|title=Handbook of Child Custody|publisher=Springer|pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=s79OCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA185&lpg=PA185&dq=%22parental+alienation%22+enmeshed&source=bl&ots=6GzVXAjF8W&sig=2ZVRNbjnqGnCIiSKEHU2pe3sA38&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CE0Q6AEwCTgyahUKEwj9sOags6fIAhXJPB4KHWTQDMI#v=onepage&q=enmeshed&f=false 186, 194, 267]|isbn=978-3319139418}}</ref><ref name=Kruk2013Reunite>{{cite web|last1=Kruk|first1=Edward|title=Parent-Child Reunification After Alienation: Strategies to Reunite Alienated Parents and Their Children|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/co-parenting-after-divorce/201305/parent-child-reunification-after-alienation|website=Psychology Today|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="BakerBreakingEnmesh">{{cite book|author = Baker, A.J.L.|title = Adult Children of Parental Alienation Syndrome: Breaking the Ties That Bind|publisher = W. W. Norton & Company|pages = |isbn = 978-0393705195|year = 2007}}</ref><ref name=Cowen2014>{{cite book|author=Philip A. Cowan|title=Family, Self, and Society: Toward A New Agenda for Family Research |publisher=Routledge |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?id=yGehAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA206&dq=minuchin+%22loss++of++psychological++boundaries%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMIstKSxZazyAIVSBc-Ch2Obg8g#v=onepage&q=minuchin%20%22loss%20%20of%20%20psychological%20%20boundaries%22&f=false 206]|isbn=978-0805809992|year=1993 }}</ref>{{mcn|date=November 2017}} and made even worse because a member of the [[Triangulation (psychology)#The Perverse Triangle|perverse triangle]] has a personality disorder,<ref name=inq/><ref name=acorn/><ref name=echo/><ref name=Greenfield2015/> climaxed by the [[Splitting (psychology)|splitting dynamic]] of the parent with the personality disorder that requires the ex-spouse to also become the ex-parent of the child.<ref name=Pingitore2015/> Finally, the child may be led to misinterpret the grief they experience from the loss of a parent as pain that means the rejected parent is abusive, since they mainly experience it in the presence of the rejected parent.<ref name=stines2015/>
===Treatment=== The success of restoring the child's [[Attachment in children|attachment]] to their parent hinges on first protecting the child from harmful parenting.<ref name=acorn/><ref name=Greenfield2015/> A study suggests that the child does not experience this protection as being traumatic.<ref name=Greenfield2015/><ref name=Kruk2015>{{cite web|last1=Kruk|first1=Edward|title=Recent Advances in Understanding Parental Alienation: Implications of Parental Alienation Research for Family-Based Intervention|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/co-parenting-after-divorce/201507/recent-advances-in-understanding-parental-alienation|website=Psychology Today|accessdate=13 September 2015}}</ref>
According to one theory,<ref name=LudmerIntervention/> when symptoms of alienation are present, structured intervention is likely to be more effective than traditional counseling. Structured intervention involves: * developing critical thinking to overcome rejection and enmeshment dynamics * resetting the child's place in the family hierarchy * addressing the family system * temporarily protecting the child from the bad parenting practices of the enmeshed parent.
Advocates of structured intervention argue that traditional counseling, based on the therapeutic alliance, is susceptible to: * delays from a lack of milestones and schedules * sabotage by a parent with an interest in making it fail * exclusive focus on a child's feelings and complaints to the exclusion of addressing the family system * the ineffectiveness of a parent apologizing for fabricated, exaggerated, or distorted complaints.
=== Other approaches === Some<ref name="inq">{{cite web|url=http://www.ccthomas.com/details.cfm?P_ISBN13=9780398088811|title=Lorandos et al. (2013). PARENTAL ALIENATION: The Handbook for Mental Health and Legal Professionals. Springfield, IL: Charles C. Thomas.|last1=|first1=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=19 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=acorn>{{cite web|last1=Bertholdo|first1=Stephanie|title=PARENT ALIENATION What happens when ex-spouses wage war with children on the front line|url=https://www.toacorn.com/articles/parent-alienation/|website=Thousand Oaks Acorn|accessdate=29 August 2015|date=2013-08-15}}</ref><ref name="echo">{{cite web|url=https://www.fact.on.ca/Info/pas/gardnr85.pdf|title=Gardner, R. A. (1985). Recent Trends in Divorce and Custody Litigation. Academy Forum, 29(2), 3-7.|last1=|first1=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=19 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=Pingitore2015>{{cite web|last1=Pingitore|first1=Marco| title=Parental Alienation, Interview with Craig Childress | url=http://www.psicologiagiuridica.eu/alienazione-parentale-intervista-craig-childress/2015/10/05/ | website=Italian Society of Forensic Science|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=LudmerIntervention>{{cite web|last1=Ludmer|first1=Brian|title=Structured intervention trumps therapy in child estrangement cases|url=http://www.advocatedaily.com/Structured-intervention-trumps-therapy-in-child-estrangement-cases.html|website=Advocate Daily|accessdate=2 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=stines2015>{{cite web|last1=Stines|first1=Sharie|title=Narcissism and Parental Alienation Syndrome|url=http://pro.psychcentral.com/recovery-expert/2015/11/narcissism-and-parental-alienation-syndrome|website=Psych Central|accessdate=8 November 2015|date=2015-11-02}}</ref> have discussed a different approach for severe cases that defines a set of psychological symptoms in a child and proposes a psychological explanation for how those symptoms were caused by harmful parenting practices and why a parent would employ those parenting practices.<ref name=inq/><ref name=acorn/><ref name=echo/> In this approach, the phenomenon is seen simply as a combination of psychological problems, each of which psychologists understand and recognize.<ref name=Greenfield2015>{{cite web|last1=Greenfield|first1=Beth|title=The Controversial Therapy That's Shaping Custody Battles|url=https://www.yahoo.com/parenting/the-controversial-therapy-thats-shaping-custody-128797596692.html|website=Yahoo Parenting|accessdate=13 September 2015}}</ref> According to this theoretical formulation, "the pathology traditionally called ‘parental alienation' are manifestations of well-established forms of existing pathologies.”<ref name=Pingitore2015/><ref name=Greenfield2015/>
== Professional acceptance == The history of parental alienation reflects an evolution of its acceptance by professionals involved in custody cases. A 2009 survey of mental health and legal professionals found broad skepticism of the concept of parental alienation syndrome, and caution in relation to the concept of parental alienation.<ref name = Bow2009/>
===Mental health professionals=== Mental health professionals are reluctant to recognize so-called parental alienation syndrome.<ref name = Bow2009/> In the past, the American Psychiatric Association and American Psychological Association<ref>{{cite web|title=Statement on Parental Alienation Syndrome|url=http://www.apa.org/news/press/releases/2008/01/pas-syndrome.aspx|website=American Psychological Association|accessdate=7 October 2017|date=1 January 2008}}</ref> have held a neutral view of parental alienation as a distinct syndrome.<ref>'Parental Alienation, DSM-5, and ICD-11: Response to Critics' William Bernet, MD and Amy J. L. Baker, PhD (2013)</ref>
In anticipation of the fifth version of the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders]], which was released in 2013, William Bernet argued for the inclusion of ''parental alienation disorder'', a diagnosis related to parental alienation. His conception makes reference to parental alienation and a variety of other descriptions of behaviors he believes represent the underlying concept of parental alienation disorder.<ref name=Bernet2008>{{cite journal | last=Bernet | first=W| title= Parental Alienation Disorder and DSM-V | journal = The American Journal of Family Therapy | volume = 36 | issue = 5 | year = 2008 | pages = 349–366 | doi = 10.1080/01926180802405513 }}</ref> Despite lobbying by proponents,<ref name="Rotstein2010">{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10046/1036018-114.stm|title=Mental health professionals getting update on definitions|last=Rotstein|first=Gary|date=February 15, 2010 |work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |accessdate=2010-03-02 }}</ref> in December 2012, the proposal was rejected.<ref>{{cite web|title=American Psychiatric Association Board of Trustees Approves DSM-5-Diagnostic manual passes major milestone before May 2013 publication|url=http://dsmfacts.org/materials/american-psychiatric-association-board-of-trustees-approves-dsm-5/|publisher=American Psychiatric Association|date=1 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005021044/http://dsmfacts.org/materials/american-psychiatric-association-board-of-trustees-approves-dsm-5/|archivedate=5 October 2013|df=}}</ref>
Some argue that elements of parental alienation are covered in the [[DSM-5]] under the diagnosis: "Parent-Child Relational Problem".<ref name="bernetw">{{cite journal|last1=Bernet|first1=William|last2=Wamboldt|first2=Marianne Z.|last3=Narrow|first3=William E.|title=Child Affected by Parental Relationship Distress|journal=Journal of the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry|date=July 2016|volume=55|issue=7|pages=571–579|url=http://www.kenniscentrum-kjp.nl/app/webroot/files/tmpwebsite/Downloadables_trauma_en_kindermishandeling_bijlagen/Bernet_et_al._-_CAPRD_-_2016-07.pdf|accessdate=7 October 2017|doi=10.1016/j.jaac.2016.04.018|pmid=27343884}}</ref> For example, the child's perception of an alienated parent "may include negative attributions of the other's intentions, hostility toward or scapegoating of the other (parent), and unwarranted feelings of estrangement".<ref>Kay, B. (2013). [http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2013/05/23/barbara-kay-teaching-children-to-hate-the-ex/ Barbara Kay: Teaching children to hate the ex] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130616033355/http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2013/05/23/barbara-kay-teaching-children-to-hate-the-ex/ |date=2013-06-16 }}. National Post, May 23, 2013.</ref><ref>Franklin, R. (2013). [https://www.nationalparentsorganization.org/recent-articles?id=20972 Limited Definition of parental alienation syndrome included in the DSM-V.] National Parent's Organization, May 26, 2013.</ref>
===Courts=== In a survey at the Association of Family and Conciliation Courts in 2010, 98% of the 300 respondents agreed with the question, "Do you think that some children are manipulated by one parent to irrationally and unjustifiably reject the other parent?".<ref name=":1">Lorandos, D., W. Bernet and S.R. Sauber (2013). Overview of Parental Alienation. In {{cite book|last1=Lorandos|first1=Demosthenes|last2=Bernet|first2=William|last3=Sauber|first3=S. Richard|title=Parental Alienation: The Handbook for Mental Health and Legal Professionals|date=2013|publisher=Charles C Thomas Publisher|isbn=978-0398087500|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mNfCCAAAQBAJ|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref> However, parental alienation refers not to the acts of manipulation, but rather to the child's rejection of a parent that results from alienating behavior.
Some courts recognize parental alienation as a form of child abuse with long-term effects and serious outcomes for the child. Some jurisdictions, including Brazil<ref>{{cite web|title=Brazil: Parental Alienation Criminalized|url=https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/brazil-parental-alienation-criminalized/|website=Library of Congress|accessdate=7 October 2017|date=2 September 2010}}</ref> and Mexico, have enacted parental alienation as a criminal offense.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hill|first1=Amelia|title=Programme aims to help people affected by 'parental alienation'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/jul/14/programme-aims-to-help-people-affected-by-parental-alienation|accessdate=7 October 2017|publisher=The Guardian|date=14 July 2016}}</ref> Other jurisdictions may suspend child support in cases where parental alienation occurs. For example, in New York, in ''Matter of Robert Coull v. Pamela Rottman'', No. 2014-01516, 2015 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 6611 (September 2, 2015), where the father was prevented from seeing his son by the child's mother through a "pattern of alienation", child support was suspended.<ref>{{ cite news | title=Father Not Obligated to Pay Child Support, Panel Finds | author=Denney, Andrew | publisher=New York Law Journal | date=9 September 2015 | url=http://www.newyorklawjournal.com/id=1202736637831/Father-Not-Obligated-to-Pay-Child-Support-Panel-Finds }}</ref> Some United States courts have also tried to address the issue through mandated reunification therapy; but no federal or state laws regulating parental alienation currently exist in the United States<ref>[http://www.wkfamilylaw.com/parental-alienation-crime/], "Should Parental Alienation Be A Crime?" - Wallin & Klarich Family Law</ref> Due to the nature of allegations of parental alienation, many courts require that a qualified expert witness testify in support of allegations of parental alienation or in association with any allegation that a parent has a mental health disorder.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Novotney|first1=Amy|title=Custody collaborations|journal=Monitor on Psychology|date=July 2008|volume=39|issue=7|page=48|url=http://www.apa.org/monitor/2008/07-08/child-custody.aspx|accessdate=7 October 2017}}</ref>
While states have broadly rejected parental alienation syndrome as a concept that may be presented in a child custody case, it remains possible to argue that parental alienation has occurred, and to demonstrate how a parent's alienating behaviors should be considered by a court when evaluating a custody case.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Aaron|title=Parental Alienation in Child Custody Cases|url=https://www.expertlaw.com/library/child_custody/parental_alienation.html|website=ExpertLaw.com|accessdate=7 October 2017|date=24 February 2016}}</ref> Behaviors that result in parental alienation may reflect other mental health disorders, both on the part of the alienating parent and the alienated parent, that may be relevant to a custody determination.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kelly|first1=Joan B.|last2=Johnston|first2=Janet R.|title=The Alienated Child: A Reformulation of Parental Alienation Syndrome|journal=Family Court Review|date=July 2001|volume=39|issue=3|pages=249–266|doi=10.1111/j.174-1617.2001.tb00609.x}}</ref> The behavior of the alienated child may also be a relevant factor.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Baker|first1=Amy J.L.|last2=Eichler|first2=Amy|title=The Linkage Between Parental Alienation Behaviors and Child Alienation|journal=Journal of Divorce and Remarriage|date=2016|volume=57|issue=7|pages=475–484|doi=10.1080/10502556.2016.1220285}}</ref>

In [[sociology of scientific knowledge]], '''Planck's principle''' is the view that scientific change does not occur because individual scientists change their mind, but rather that successive generations of scientists have different views.
The reason for the name is the statements by [[Max Planck]]:<ref>Planck, Max K. (1950). Scientific Autobiography and Other Papers. New York: Philosophical library.</ref>
{{quote|text=A new scientific truth does not triumph by convincing its opponents and making them see the light, but rather because its opponents eventually die and a new generation grows up that is familiar with it|sign=Max Planck|source=Scientific autobiography, 1950, p. 33}} {{quote|text=An important scientific innovation rarely makes its way by gradually winning over and converting its opponents: it rarely happens that Saul becomes Paul. What does happen is that its opponents gradually die out, and that the growing generation is familiarized with the ideas from the beginning: another instance of the fact that the future lies with the youth.|sign=Max Planck|source=Scientific autobiography, 1950, p. 97}}
Planck's quote has been used by [[Thomas Kuhn]], [[Paul Feyerabend]] and others to argue that [[scientific revolutions]] are arational, rather than spreading through "mere force of truth and fact".<ref name="Hull">{{cite journal |vauthors=Hull DL, Tessner PD, Diamond AM |title=Planck's Principle |journal=Science |date=17 November 1978 |volume=202 |issue=4369 |pages=717–23 |doi=10.1126/science.202.4369.717}}</ref><ref>T. Kuhn. ''[[The Structure of Scientific Revolutions]]''. University of Chicago Press, 1970. p. 151</ref><ref>P. Feyrabend, in Criticism and the growth of knowledge, I. Lakatos and A. Musgrave, eds. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge 1970, p. 203</ref><ref>Pierre Azoulay, Christian Fons-Rosen, Joshua S. Graff Zivin: Does Science Advance One Funeral at a Time? 2015, {{doi|10.3386/w21788}}.</ref> It has been described as [[Darwinian]] rather than [[Lamarckian]] conceptual evolution.<ref>{{cite journal |author=John T. Blackmore |year=1978 |title=Is Planck's 'Principle' True? |journal=British Journal for the Philosophy of Science |volume=29 |issue=4 |pages=347–349 |jstor=687097}}</ref>
Whether age influences the readiness to accept new ideas has been empirically criticised. In the case of acceptance of [[evolution]] in the years after Darwin's ''[[On the Origin of Species]]'' age was a minor factor.<ref name="Hull"/> Similarly, it was a weak factor in accepting [[cliometrics]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Arthur M. Diamond, Jr. |title=Age and the Acceptance of Cliometrics |journal=The Journal of Economic History |volume=40 |issue=4 |date=December 1980 |jstor=2120004}}</ref>

In [[sociology]] and [[economics]], the '''precariat''' ({{IPAc-en|p|r|ɪ|ˈ|k|ɛər|i|ə|t}}) is a [[social class]] formed by people suffering from [[precarity]], which is a condition of [[existence]] without [[predictability]] or [[security]], affecting material or [[psychology|psychological]] welfare. The term is a [[portmanteau]] obtained by merging ''[[wiktionary:precarious|precarious]]'' with ''[[proletariat]]''.<ref>F. Lunning (2010).[https://books.google.com/books?id=5d0Q9fdinQUC&pg=PA252&dq=precariat+proletariat&hl=en&ei=XAtzTpGLO46Tswb4pJmOCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=precariat%20proletariat&f=false'' Mechademia 5: Fanthropologies'']. University of Minnesota Press. p. 252. {{ISBN|081667387X}}.</ref> Unlike the proletariat class of industrial workers in the 20th century who lacked their own means of production and hence sold their labour to live, members of the precariat are only partially involved in labour and must undertake extensive "unremunerated activities that are essential if they are to retain access to jobs and to decent earnings". Specifically, it is the condition of lack of [[job security]], including intermittent employment or [[underemployment]] and the resultant precarious existence.<ref name="pn4004">[[Guy Standing (economist)|Guy Standing]] (May 24, 2011). [http://www.policy-network.net/articles/4004/-The-Precariat-%E2%80%93-The-new-dangerous-class "The Precariat – The new dangerous class"]. Policy Network.</ref> The emergence of this class has been ascribed to the entrenchment of [[neoliberal]] [[capitalism]].<ref>Lorna Fox O'Mahony, David O'Mahony and Robin Hickey (eds), ''[http://www.routledge.com/books/details/9780415740616/ Moral Rhetoric and the Criminalisation of Squatting: Vulnerable Demons?]'' (London: [[Routledge]], 2014), {{ISBN|0415740614}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=qyIcBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA25 p. 25].</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Marginality, ethnicity and penality in the neo-liberal city: an analytic cartography |author=Wacquant, Loïc |authorlink=Loïc Wacquant |journal=[[Ethnic and Racial Studies]] |url=http://www.loicwacquant.net/assets/Papers/MARGINALITYETHNICITYPENALITY-Article-ERS.pdf |date=2014 |volume=37 |issue=10 |pages=1687–1711 |doi=10.1080/01419870.2014.931991 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151010112131/http://www.loicwacquant.net/assets/Papers/MARGINALITYETHNICITYPENALITY-Article-ERS.pdf |archivedate=2015-10-10 |df= }}</ref>
==Overview== The young precariat class in Europe has become a serious issue in the early part of the 21st century,<ref>Press Europe: September 15, 2011: The "Youthful members of the full-time precariat [http://www.presseurop.eu/en/content/article/953511-youthful-members-full-time-precariat].</ref> and has been linked with major populist political developments including the [[Brexit]] referendum and the [[presidency of Donald Trump]].<ref name=wef>{{cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2016/11/precariat-global-class-rise-of-populism|title=Meet the precariat, the new global class fuelling the rise of populism|author=Guy Standing|date=2016-11-09|publisher=World Economic Forum}}</ref>
The British economist [[Guy Standing (economist)|Guy Standing]] has analysed the precariat as a new emerging [[social class]] in work done for the think tank [[Policy Network]] and the [[World Economic Forum]].<ref name=wef /> In 2014, he wrote another book titled ''A Precariat Charter'' where he argued that all citizens have a right to socially inherited wealth.<ref>[[Guy Standing (economist)|Guy Standing]]. ''A Precariat Charter''. Bloomsbury Academic. 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Crocker|first1=Geoff|title=The Economic Necessity of Basic Income|url=http://www.centreforwelfarereform.org/library/by-date/the-economic-necessity-of-basic-income.html|accessdate=23 November 2015}}</ref> The latest in the series is titled ''[[The Precariat: The New Dangerous Class]]''<ref name="pn4004"/><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jun/01/voice-for-emerging-precariat "Who will be a voice for the emerging precariat?"], ''The Guardian'', June 1, 2011.</ref> where he proposed [[basic income]] as a solution for addressing the problem.
The analysis of the results of the [[Great British Class Survey]] of 2013, a collaboration between the [[BBC]] and researchers from several UK universities, contended there is a new model of class structure consisting of seven classes, ranging from the [[Elite]] at the top to the Precariat at the bottom.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Great British Class Survey – Results |author=Mike Savage and Fiona Devine |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/science/0/21970879 |publisher=[[BBC|BBC Science]] |date=April 3, 2013 |accessdate=April 7, 2013}}</ref> The Precariat class was envisaged as "the most deprived British class of all with low levels of economic, cultural and social capital" and the opposite of "the Technical Middle Class" in Great Britain in that instead of having money but no interests, people of the new Precariat Class have all sorts of potential activities they like to engage in but cannot do any of them because they have no money, insecure lives, and are usually trapped in old industrial parts of the country.
The precariat class has been emerging in societies such as [[Japan]], where it includes over 20 million so-called "[[freeter]]s".<ref>Machiko Osawa and Jeff Kingston (July 1, 2010). [http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/359fa9a8-8545-11df-9c2f-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1Y0hvtoZ1 "Japan has to address the ‘precariat’"]. ''[[The Financial Times]]''.</ref>

''[[Jacobin (magazine)|Jacobin]]'', April 20, 2015.

A '''private currency''' is a [[currency]] issued by a private entity, be it an individual, a commercial business, a nonprofit or [[decentralization|decentralized]] common enterprise. It is often contrasted with [[fiat currency]] issued by [[Forms of government|governments]] or [[central bank]]s. In many countries, the issuance of private paper currencies and new [[cryptocurrency]] is severely restricted by law, while the minting of metal coins intended to be used as currency may even be a criminal act such as in the USA (18 U.S. Code § 486).<ref>{{cite web|title=18 U.S. Code § 486 - Uttering coins of gold, silver or other metal|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/486|accessdate=7 July 2018|language=English}}</ref>
Today, there are over four thousand privately issued currencies in more than 35 countries. These include commercial [[Barter#Trade exchanges|trade exchanges]] that use barter credits as units of exchange, private gold and silver exchanges, local paper money, computerized systems of credits and debits, and [[digital currencies]] in circulation, such as [[digital gold currency]].
== Private bank notes == [[File:Delaware Bridge Company Dollar.jpg|thumb|right|A private $1 note, issued by the "Delaware Bridge Company" of [[New Jersey]] 1836–1841]]
In the [[United States]], the [[History of banking in the United States#1837%E2%80%931863:_%22Free_Banking%22_Era|Free Banking Era]] lasted between 1837 and 1866, when almost anyone could issue paper money. States, municipalities, [[private bank]]s, railroad and construction companies, stores, restaurants, churches and individuals printed an estimated 8,000 different types of money by 1860. If an issuer went bankrupt, closed, left town, or otherwise went out of business, the note would be worthless. Such organizations earned the nickname of "wildcat banks" for a reputation of unreliability; they were often situated in remote, unpopulated locales said to be inhabited more by wildcats than by people. The [[National Bank Act of 1863]] ended the "wildcat bank" period. See also: [[Free banking#History of free banking|History of free banking]].
[[File:The City Bank Of Sydney 20 pound note.jpg|thumb|right|Private currency issued in Australia by The City Bank of Sydney circa 1900]] In [[Australia]], the [[Bank Notes Tax Act 1910]] effectively shut down the circulation of private currencies by imposing a prohibitive tax on the practice. The Act was repealed by the ''Commonwealth Bank Act'' 1945, which imposed a fine for private currencies.
Now, s. 44(1) of the Australian ''Reserve Bank Act 1959'',<ref>{{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|rba1959130|Reserve Bank Act 1959|44}} Other persons not to issue notes.</ref> prohibits this practice. In 1976, [[Wickrema Weerasooria]] published an article which suggested that the issuing of [[bank cheque]]s violated this section, though some banks responded that since bank cheques were printed with the words "not negotiable" on them, the cheques were not intended for circulation and thus did not violate the statute.<ref>{{cite web |last=Weerasooria |first=Wickrema |title=The Australian Bank Cheque - Some Legal Aspects |url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/MonashULawRw/1976/3.pdf}} (1976) 2(2) Monash University Law Review 180. {{issn|0311-3140}}</ref>
In [[Hong Kong]], although the government issues currency, bank-issued private currency is the dominant medium of exchange. Most [[automated teller machine]]s dispense private [[Banknotes of the Hong Kong dollar|Hong Kong bank notes]].<ref>International Bank Note Society. [http://www.theibns.org/joomla/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=232&catid=13&Itemid=51 "Hong Kong's 1,000 (HSBC) dollar note"].</ref>
In [[Scotland]], the [[Bank of Scotland]], [[Clydesdale Bank]], and the [[Royal Bank of Scotland]], and in [[Northern Ireland]], the [[Bank of Ireland]], [[Danske Bank]], [[First Trust Bank]], and [[Ulster Bank]], are authorised by [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] to issue [[Pound sterling]] bank notes. They are subject to [[central bank]] (the [[Bank of England]]) regulations concerning "ring-fenced backing assets" and are backed in part by deposits at the Bank of England. They are exchangeable with other pound notes on a one-to-one basis, and circulate freely within the United Kingdom, though not legal tender, not even in Scotland and Northern Ireland. In fact, technically, no banknote (including Bank of England notes) qualifies as legal tender in Scotland or Northern Ireland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acbi.org.uk/media/sni_notes_factsheet_nov12_copy1.pdf|author=The Association of Commercial Banknote Issuers|title=Scottish and Northern Ireland Banknotes Fact Sheet}}</ref>
== Complementary currencies == {{main|Complementary currency}} <!-- Unsourced Many private currencies are [[community currency|community]] or [[local currency|local]] currencies, types of [[complementary currency]].
Since 1991, residents of and around the city of [[Ithaca, New York|Ithaca]] in Western New York State have been using a private currency in which participating workers either earn or purchase [[Ithaca Hours]], which may be used to buy goods and services locally. The system has been ruled legal provided all Hours-derived revenues are reported to the IRS as income{{Citation needed|date=March 2014}}.
[[BerkShares]] is a local currency that circulates in [[The Berkshires]] region of [[Massachusetts]]. It was launched on September 29, 2006 by BerkShares Inc., with research and development assistance from the [[E. F. Schumacher Society]]. The BerkShares website lists over 370 businesses in Berkshire County that accept the currency. In 30 months, 2.2 million BerkShares have been issued from 12 branch offices of five local banks.-->
[[England]] has had the [[Totnes pound]] since it was launched by [[Transition Towns]] Totnes Economics and Livelihoods Group in March 2007; A Totnes Pound is equal to one pound sterling and is backed by sterling held in a bank account. As at September 2008, about 70 businesses in Totnes were accepting the Totnes Pound. Other local currencies launched since then include the [[Lewes Pound]] (2008), the [[Brixton#Brixton Pound|Brixton Pound]] (2009),<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|title=Will the Brixton pound buy a brighter future?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2009/sep/16/will-brixton-pound-work|author=Leo Hickman|date=16 September 2009|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref> the [[Stroud Pound]] (2009)<ref name="Mail Feb 12">{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Tom|title=We don't want to be part of 'clone town Britain': City launches its own currency to keep money local|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2097398/Bristol-pound-City-launches-currency-money-local.html?ito=feeds-newsxml|accessdate=23 September 2012|newspaper=Daily Mail|date=6 February 2012}}</ref> and the [[Bristol Pound]], which also allows for electronic payments.<ref name="BBC Sept12">{{cite news|last=Harvey|first=Dave|title=Bristol Pound launched to keep trade in the city|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-bristol-19627592|accessdate=21 September 2012|newspaper=BBC West News|date=19 September 2012}}</ref>
[[Austria]] had the [[Wörgl]] Experiment from July 1932 to September 1933.
[[Bavaria]], [[Germany]], has had the [[Chiemgauer]] since 2003. As of 2011 there were over 550,000 in circulation.<ref name="BBC Sept12"/>
Since starting in 2006, the "City Initiative [[Karlsruhe]]" has issued the ''Karlsruher'' which has no nominal value. Every coin has the value of 50 Eurocents and is primarily used in parking garages. As of 2009, 120 companies in Karlsruhe accept the ''Karlsruher'' and usually grant a discount when paid with it.<ref>{{cite web|title=Karlsruhe (bonus system)|url=http://ka.stadtwiki.net/Karlsruher_%28Bonussystem%29|accessdate=15 April 2014|language=German}}</ref>
In [[Canada]], numerous complementary currencies are in use, such as the [[Calgary Dollar]] and [[Toronto dollar]]. However private currencies in Canada cannot be referred to as being legal tender and many private currencies (as well as loyalty programs) avoid the word "dollar", using names like "coupons" or "bucks", to avoid confusion. Examples include: [[Canadian Tire money]] and [[Pioneer Energy#Bonus Bucks|Pioneer Energy's Bonus Bucks]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}}
Customer reward and [[loyalty program]]s operated by businesses are sometimes counted as private currencies. However, though "points" or "[[frequent flyer program|miles]]" may be exchangeable for merchandise or travel from the program sponsor, most of them lack the key element for currency of being a medium of exchange transferable to other individuals and usable as payment for items from other vendors. A few programs do have "partnerships" allowing this to some extent, and permit the transfer of points or miles. Some startups, such as the Canadian website Points.com,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://points.com|title=Points.com|website="points.com"}}</ref> have sought to make loyalty "points" more currency-like by creating an exchange where points from one loyalty program can be traded for points in other such programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2369584,00.asp|title=Points.com establishes currency exchange for loyalty programs|website=www.pcmag.com}}</ref>
== Cryptocurrencies and digital currencies == A [[cryptocurrency]] is a form of [[digital currency|digital]] or [[virtual currency]] where [[cryptography]] secures the transactions and controls the creation of additional units of the currency.<ref name="crypto currency">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2011/0509/technology-psilocybin-bitcoins-gavin-andresen-crypto-currency.html |title=Crypto Currency |author=Andy Greenberg|publisher=Forbes.com |date=20 April 2011 |accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref> A [[cryptocurrency wallet]] can be used to store the public and private keys which can be used to receive or spend the cryptocurrency. The cryptographic systems used allow for decentralisation; a decentralised cryptocurrency is [[fiat money]] but one without a central banking system. In terms of total market value, [[Bitcoin]] is the largest cryptocurrency,<ref name="WsjVolatile">{{cite news |last=Espinoza |first=Javier |title=Is It Time to Invest in Bitcoin? Cryptocurrencies Are Highly Volatile, but Some Say They Are Worth It |date=22 September 2014 |url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/how-to-decipher-cryptocurrencies-1411333011 |work=Journal Reports |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> but there are over 700<ref>{{cite web|title=coinmarketcap.com|url=http://coinmarketcap.com/all/views/all/|accessdate=13 July 2016}}</ref> digital currencies in existence.
On 6 August 2013, Federal Judge Amos Mazzant of the [[Eastern District of Texas]] of the [[Fifth Circuit]] ruled that bitcoins are "a currency or a form of money" (specifically securities as defined by Federal Securities Laws), and as such were subject to the court's jurisdiction.<ref>{{cite web|last=Farivar |first=Cyrus |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2013/08/federal-judge-bitcoin-a-currency-can-be-regulated-under-american-law/ |title=Federal judge: Bitcoin, "a currency," can be regulated under American law |publisher=Ars Technica |date=2013-08-07 |accessdate=2013-08-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Securities and Exchange Commission v. Shavers et al, 4:13-cv-00416 (E.D.Tex.)|url=https://www.docketalarm.com/cases/Texas_Eastern_District_Court/4--13-cv-00416/Securities_and_Exchange_Commission_v._Shavers_et_al/|publisher=Docket Alarm, Inc.|accessdate=14 August 2013}}</ref> In August 2013, the German Finance Ministry characterized Bitcoin as a [[unit of account]],<ref name="Marketwatch20130819"/><ref name=FAZ20130816/> usable in [[Clearing house (finance)|multilateral clearing circles]] and subject to capital gains tax if held less than one year.<ref name=FAZ20130816>{{cite news|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/finanzen/devisen-rohstoffe/digitale-waehrung-deutschland-erkennt-bitcoins-als-privates-geld-an-12535059.html|title=Deutschland erkennt Bitcoins als privates Geld an (Germany recognizes Bitcoin as private money) |last=Nestler |first=Franz|date=16 August 2013 |website=[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]]}}</ref><ref name=Marketwatch20130819>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.marketwatch.com/thetell/2013/08/19/bitcoins-are-private-money-in-germany/ |title=Bitcoins are private money in Germany |last=Vaishampayan |first=Saumya |date=19 August 2013 |website=[[Marketwatch]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6JJIqfMJn?url=http://blogs.marketwatch.com/thetell/2013/08/19/bitcoins-are-private-money-in-germany/ |archivedate=1 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In Thailand, lack of existing law leads many to believe Bitcoin is banned.<ref>{{cite web|last=Watts|first=Jake Maxwell|title=Thailand’s Bitcoin ban is not quite what it seems|url=http://qz.com/110164/thailands-infamous-bitcoin-crackdown-is-not-quite-what-it-seems/|publisher=Quartz|accessdate=15 April 2014}}</ref>
== Private currency crimes ==
As national currencies can be [[counterfeit]]ed, so too can private currencies, and private currencies are subject to other criminal issues, including [[fraud]].
The [[Liberty dollar (private currency)|Liberty Dollar]] was a commodity-backed private currency created by [[Bernard von NotHaus]] and issued between 1998 and 2009. In 2011, von NotHaus was arrested and subsequently convicted on charges of [[money laundering]], [[mail fraud]], [[wire fraud]], [[counterfeiting]], and [[Conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]].<ref>{{cite press release |title=Defendant Convicted of Minting His Own Currency |publisher=[[United States Attorney|U.S. Attorney's Office]] |date=March 18, 2011 |location=[[United States District Court for the Western District of North Carolina]] |url=https://www.fbi.gov/charlotte/press-releases/2011/defendant-convicted-of-minting-his-own-currency |archivedate=December 17, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CygqRiVv?url=http://www.fbi.gov/charlotte/press-releases/2011/defendant-convicted-of-minting-his-own-currency |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Tom |last=Lovett |title=Local Liberty Dollar 'Architect' Bernard von NotHaus convicted |date=March 19, 2011 |publisher=Evansville Courier & Press |url=http://www.courierpress.com/news/2011/mar/19/local-liberty-dollar-architect-found-guilty/}}</ref> The charges stemmed from the government view that the Liberty silver coins too closely resembled official coinage.
In 2007, Angel Cruz, founder of The United Cities Corporation (TUC), announced he was establishing an alternative "asset based" currency named "United States Private Dollars".<ref>[http://www.dailykos.com/story/2007/8/25/93036/7434/248/376052 "Florida man launches 'United States Private Dollar'"], ''[[Daily Kos]]'', August 25, 2007.</ref> Cruz claimed United States Private Dollars were "backed by the total net worth of the assets of its members" and had printed six billion dollars' worth of the private currency,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080112204706/http://www.theunitedcities.org/web/content/view/15/14/ "TUC Currencies", United Cities website], via [[Internet Archive]]</ref> The backing assets were claimed to be valued at 357 billion dollars.<ref>[http://openpr.com/news/25136/TUC-IMPROVING-THE-US-ECONOMY-BY-THE-CIRCULATION-OF-THEIR-PRIVATE-CURRENCY-TODAY.html "TUC Improving the US Economy by the Circulation of Their Private Currency Today", OpenPR.com] August 2, 2007</ref> The currency featured the slogan "In Jehovah We Trust".<ref name="articles.orlandosentinel.com">[http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2007-08-25/news/MONEYSCAM25_1_kissimmee-nonprofit-united-cities "Kissimmee nonprofit 'concerned' over checks"], ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'', August 25, 2007</ref> The [[Comptroller of the Currency]] issued an alert warning banks that checks issued by TUC were "valueless instruments" and should not be cashed.<ref name="articles.orlandosentinel.com"/> In 2008, Cruz was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Florida on one count of conspiracy to defraud the United States under {{usc|18|1344}} and {{usc|18|371}} and six counts of bank fraud under {{usc|18|1344}} and {{usc|18|2}} in connection with his dealings with Bank of America, while attempting to get United Cities bank drafts cashed.<ref>Indictment, ''United States v. Cruz'', case no. 6:08-cr-00177-UA-DAB, docket entry 1, Aug. 6, 2008, U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida (Orlando Div.).</ref> As of late October 2010, Cruz was still a fugitive,<ref>Status Report, ''United States v. Cruz'', case no. 6:08-cr-00177-UA-DAB, docket entry 88, Oct. 28, 2010, U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Florida (Orlando Div.)</ref> though an associate was convicted on related charges and sentenced to prison for eight years.

{{cleanup|date=March 2012}} A '''rate gyro''' is a type of [[gyroscope]], which rather than indicating direction, indicates the rate of change of angle with time. If a gyro has only one gimbal ring, with consequently only one plane of freedom, it can be adapted for use as a rate gyro to measure a rate of angular movement.
Rate gyros are used in [[rate integrating gyroscope]]s, and in [[attitude control system]]s for vehicles, and in combination with other sensors to make [[inertial navigation system]]s.
The advantage of rate gyros over other types of gyros is the fast response rate and their relatively low cost.
==Principles==
===Spinning=== The traditional type of rate gyro employs relatively conventional gyroscopes with viscous couplings to transfer the spin rate to allow it to be read. * [http://usdynamicscorp.com/literature/general/AN-001%20USD%20Rate%20Gyroscope.pdf US Dynamics Rate Gyroscope Technical Brief]
===Vibrating structure gyroscope=== {{main|Vibrating structure gyroscope}} MEMS gyros are cheap and have no moving parts. They often work by sonic resonance effects driven by [[piezoelectric]] transducers, that provide a signal when a rotation occurs.
==External links== * [http://usdynamicscorp.com/literature/general/475_series.pdf Spinning Mass Rate Gyroscopes]
